and the Ethics of Appropriation|first1=Alexa|last1=Huang|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Rivlin|date=23 October 2014|publisher=Springer|page=198|accessdate=10 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> ** In [[Maori language|Maori]], with English subtitles. This film was based on a 1945 translation of the play to Maori by [[Pei Te Hurinui Jones]].<ref name="auto5"/> * 2003 – In ''Shakespeare's Merchant'', a film directed by Paul Wagar, Antonio and Bassanio has a homosexual relationship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=MbDeCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT96&dq=%22Shakespeare's+Merchant%22+%22PAUL+WAGAR%22&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1oquG7P7dAhUHDSwKHVZJD8AQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=%22Shakespeare's+Merchant%22+%22PAUL+WAGAR%22&f=false|title=Shakespeare and Immigration|first=Ruben|last=Espinosa|date=1 April 2016|publisher=Routledge|accessdate=11 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=lycmDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA17&dq=%22Shakespeare's+Merchant%22+%22PAUL+WAGAR%22&hl=sv&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1oquG7P7dAhUHDSwKHVZJD8AQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=%22Shakespeare's+Merchant%22+%22PAUL+WAGAR%22&f=false|title=For the Gay Stage: A Guide to 456 Plays, Aristophanes to Peter Gill|first=Drewey Wayne|last=Gunn|date=19 May 2017|publisher=McFarland|page=17|accessdate=11 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> * 2004 – ''[[The Merchant of Venice (2004 film)|The Merchant of Venice]]'', directed by [[Michael Radford]] and produced by Barry Navidi. ** This was the first "big-screen" adaption of the play. The cast included [[Al Pacino]] as Shylock, [[Jeremy Irons]] as Antonio, [[Joseph Fiennes]] as Bassanio, [[Lynn Collins]] as Portia, and [[Zuleikha Robinson]] as Jessica.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bostonreview.net/alan-stone-redeeming-shylock|title=Redeeming Shylock|first=|last=Intern|date=2 July 2012|website=Boston Review|accessdate=11 October 2018}}</ref> * 2018 - ''The Merchant of Venice'', adapted and directed by Emma Harding. ** Broadcast on [[BBC Radio 3]] on 22 April 2018 and transposing the plot from Venice to the City of London and the [[2008 financial crash]]. The cast included [[Andrew Scott (actor)|Andrew Scott]] as Shylock, [[Ray Fearon]] as Antonio, [[Colin Morgan]] as Bassanio, [[Hayley Atwell]] as Portia, and Lauren Cornelius as Jessica.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.spectator.co.uk/2018/04/all-the-worlds-a-stage-2/|title=How do you make Shakespeare work on the radio? - The Spectator|date=28 April 2018|publisher=|accessdate=11 October 2018}}</ref>
=== Operas === * [[Josef Bohuslav Foerster]]'s three-act Czech opera ''Jessika'' was first performed at the [[National Theatre (Prague)|Prague National Theatre]] in 1905.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=1C0KAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Merchant+of+Venice%22+%22Josef+Bohuslav+Foerster%22+jessika&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=jessika|title=Symphonic Program Music and Its Literary Sources|first=Lawrence|last=Casler|date=1 January 2001|publisher=Edwin Mellen Press|accessdate=11 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=Ff6wDAAAQBAJ&pg=RA2-PA10&dq=%22Merchant+of+Venice%22+%22Josef+Bohuslav+Foerster%22+jessika&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi7ibbfjf_dAhUFDZAKHctABR8Q6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=%22Merchant+of+Venice%22+%22Josef+Bohuslav+Foerster%22+jessika&f=false|title=The Bard and the Bible: A Shakespeare Devotional|first=Bob|last=Hostetler|date=9 August 2016|publisher=Worthy Publishing|accessdate=11 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> * [[Reynaldo Hahn]]'s three-act French opera ''[[Le marchand de Venise]]'' was first performed at the [[Paris Opéra]] on 25 March 1935.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=lZdvAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA144&dq=%22Le+marchand+de+Venise%22+hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO__f_kv_dAhXCiJAKHU_NBzcQ6AEILzAC#v=onepage&q=%22Le+marchand+de+Venise%22+hahn&f=false|title=Edinburgh Companion to Shakespeare and the Arts|first=Mark Thornton|last=Burnett|date=12 October 2011|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|accessdate=11 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=JAQJAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Le+marchand+de+Venise%22+hahn&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=marchand|title=The Paris Opéra: an encyclopedia of operas, ballets, composers, and performers|first=Spire|last=Pitou|date=11 October 1990|publisher=Greenwood Press|accessdate=11 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> * The late [[André Tchaikowsky]]'s (1935–1982) opera ''The Merchant of Venice'' premiered at the [[Bregenz Festival]]<ref>[http://www.bregenzerfestspiele.com/en/node/2820 "The Merchant of Venice – World premiere", Bregenzer Festspiele.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202235612/http://www.bregenzerfestspiele.com/en/node/2820 |date=2 December 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://andretchaikowsky.com/composer/merchant_of_venice.htm|title=Andre Tchaikowsky Composer|website=andretchaikowsky.com|accessdate=16 September 2018}}</ref> on 18 July 2013.
=== Cultural references === [[Edmond Haraucourt]], French playwright and poet, was commissioned in the 1880s by the actor and theatrical director Paul Porel to make a French-verse adaptation of ''The Merchant of Venice''. His play ''Shylock'', first performed at the [[Théâtre de l'Odéon]] in December 1889, had incidental music by the French composer [[Gabriel Fauré]], later incorporated into an orchestral suite of the same name.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Jean-Michel|last=Nectoux|title=Gabriel Fauré: A musical life|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1991|isbn=0-521-23524-3|pages=143–46|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
[[Ralph Vaughan Williams]]' choral work ''[[Serenade to Music]]'' (1938) draws its text from the discussion about music and the music of the spheres in Act V, scene 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=1ROAAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA127&dq=%22Serenade+to+Music%22+williams+%22Merchant+of+Venice%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidsNGwoNjdAhVGt1MKHc9QBdoQ6AEIMTAC#v=onepage&q=%22Serenade+to+Music%22+williams+%22Merchant+of+Venice%22&f=false|title=The Cambridge Companion to Vaughan Williams|first1=Alain|last1=Frogley|first2=Aidan J.|last2=Thomson|date=14 November 2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=127|accessdate=26 September 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In both versions of the comic film ''To Be or Not to Be'' ([[To Be or Not to Be (1942 film)|1942]] and [[To Be or Not to Be (1983 film)|1983]]) the character "Greenberg", specified as a Jew in the later version, gives a recitation of the "Hath Not a Jew eyes?" speech to Nazi soldiers.<ref name="Bernardi2001">{{cite book|last1=Sammond|first1=Nicholas|last2=Mukerji|first2=Chandra|editor=[[Daniel Bernardi|Bernardi, Daniel]]|title=Classic Hollywood, Classic Whiteness|year=2001|publisher=University of Minnesota Press|location=Minneapolis|isbn=0-8166-3239-1|pages=15–27}}</ref>
The rock musical ''Fire Angel'' was based on the story of the play, with the scene changed to the Little Italy district of New York. It was performed in Edinburgh in 1974 and in a revised form at [[Her Majesty's Theatre]], London, in 1977. [[Braham Murray]] directed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bufvc.ac.uk/shakespeare/index.php/title/av37348|title=Fire Angel · British Universities Film & Video Council|website=bufvc.ac.uk|accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=mt4MAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Fire+Angel%22+%22Merchant+of+Venice%22+Murray&dq=%22Fire+Angel%22+%22Merchant+of+Venice%22+Murray&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3oYziru_dAhWKOSwKHW5DAVYQ6AEINTAC|title=Jewish Observer and Middle East Review|date=5 October 1977|publisher=William Samuel & Company Limited|accessdate=5 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
[[Arnold Wesker]]'s play ''[[The Merchant (play)|The Merchant]]'' (1976) is a reimagening of Shakespeare's story.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/14/theater/arnold-wesker-british-playwright-known-for-working-class-dramas-dies-at-83.html|title=Arnold Wesker, 83, Writer of Working-Class Dramas, Dies|publisher=|accessdate=16 September 2018}}</ref> In this retelling, Shylock and Antonio are friends and share a disdain for the crass anti-Semitism of the Christian community's laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/apr/13/arnold-wesker-radical-bard-of-working-britain-class-plays|title=Arnold Wesker: the radical bard of working Britain|first=Michael|last=Billington|date=13 April 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=16 September 2018}}</ref>
[[David Henry Wilson]]'s play ''Shylock's Revenge'', was first produced at the [[University of Hamburg]] in 1989, and follows the events in ''The Merchant of Venice''. In this play Shylock gets his wealth back and becomes a Jew again.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?hl=sv&id=1zMofz4P_8sC&dq=%22David+Henry+Wilson%22+%22Shylock's+Revenge%22&q=%22Shylock's+Revenge%22#v=snippet&q=%22Shylock's+Revenge%22&f=false|title=Shylock: A Legend and Its Legacy|first=John|last=Gross|date=4 January 1994|publisher=Simon and Schuster|page=335|accessdate=20 September 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
The ''[[Star Trek]]'' franchise sometimes quote and paraphrase Shakespeare, including ''The Merchant of Venice''. One example is the Shakespeare-aficionado [[Chang (Star Trek)|Chang]] in ''[[Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country]]'' (1991), a [[Klingon]], who quotes Shylock.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=wfVsAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=%22Star+Trek%22+%22Merchant+of+Venice%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQjueSysvdAhUwtIsKHWF2A-0Q6AEIMTAC#v=onepage&q=%22Star+Trek%22+%22Merchant+of+Venice%22&f=false|title=Faith, Reason, and Political Life Today|first1=Peter Augustine|last1=Lawler|first2=Dale|last2=McConkey|date=21 March 2001|publisher=Lexington Books|page=29|accessdate=21 September 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
[[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Schindler's List]]'' (1993) depicts SS Lieutenant [[Amon Göth]] quoting Shylock's "Hath Not a Jew eyes?" speech when deciding whether or not to rape his Jewish maid.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=LYXMCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA93&dq=Hath+Not+a+Jew+eyes?+pianist+Szpilman&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3wMajo9jdAhWHrVMKHfK6CqYQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=Hath+Not+a+Jew+eyes?+pianist+Szpilman&f=false|title=Filming Shakespeare in the Global Marketplace|first=M.|last=Burnett|date=31 January 2007|publisher=Springer|pages=93–94|accessdate=26 September 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In [[David Fincher]]'s 1995 crime thriller ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Seven]]'', a lawyer, Eli Gould, is coerced to remove a pound of his own flesh and place it on a scale, alluding to the play.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?hl=sv&id=gZr0qFS2Vt4C&dq=%22Merchant+of+Venice%22+%22pound+of+flesh%22+seven+%22brad+pitt%22&q=%22Merchant+of+Venice%22#v=snippet&q=%22Merchant+of+Venice%22&f=false|title=Riddles, Knights, and Cross-dressing Saints: Essays on Medieval English Language and Literature|first=Thomas|last=Honegger|date=9 October 2018|publisher=Peter Lang|page=5|accessdate=9 October 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
One of the four short stories comprising [[Alan Isler]]'s ''The Bacon Fancier'' (1999) is also told from Shylock's point of view. In this story, Antonio was a converted Jew.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/books/97/06/22/reviews/970622.22saynort.html|title=The Joy of Theft|website=archive.nytimes.com|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref>
''[[The Pianist (2002 film)|The Pianist]]'' is a 2002 film based on [[The Pianist (memoir)|a memoir]] by [[Władysław Szpilman]]. In this film, Henryk Szpilman reads Shylock's "Hath Not a Jew eyes?" speech to his brother Władysław in the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] during the [[Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)|Nazi occupation]] in [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.se/books?id=LYXMCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA93&dq=Hath+Not+a+Jew+eyes?+pianist+Szpilman&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3wMajo9jdAhWHrVMKHfK6CqYQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=Hath+Not+a+Jew+eyes?+pianist+Szpilman&f=false|title=Filming Shakespeare in the Global Marketplace|first=M.|last=Burnett|date=31 January 2007|publisher=Springer|page=93|accessdate=26 September 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref>
In the 2009 spy comedy ''[[OSS 117: Lost in Rio]]'', a speech by the nazi Von Zimmel parodies Shylock's tirade.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/07/movies/07oss.html|title=French Spy Spoof Set in Swinging ’67 Rio|first=Mike|last=Hale|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://jewishweek.timesofisrael.com/blame-it-on-rio/|title=Blame It On Rio|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref>
[[Christopher Moore (author)|Christopher Moore]] combines ''The Merchant of Venice'' and ''[[Othello]]'' in his 2014 comic novel ''The Serpent of Venice'', in which he makes Portia (from ''The Merchant of Venice'') and Desdemona (from ''Othello'') sisters. All of the characters come from those two plays with the exception of Pocket, the Fool, who comes from Moore's earlier novel based on ''[[King Lear]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.seattletimes.com/html/books/2023452962_mooreserpentvenicexml.html|title=‘The Serpent of Venice’: a Shakespeare-Poe mash-up|publisher=|accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref>
[[Naomi Alderman]]'s ''The Wolf in the Water'' is a radio-play first broadcast on [[BBC Radio 3]] in 2016. The play continues the story of Shylock's daughter Jessica, who lives in an anti-semitic Venice and practices her Jewish faith in secret. Part of the BBC's Shakespeare Festival, the play also marked that 500 years had passed since the [[Venetian Ghetto]] was instituted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07bvjcs|title=The Wolf in the Water, Drama on 3 - BBC Radio 3|website=BBC|accessdate=16 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/the-merchant-of-venice-what-happened-next-6lpfgvc3p|title=The Merchant of Venice: what happened next|first=Naomi|last=Alderman|date=7 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=9 October 2018|via=www.thetimes.co.uk}}</ref>
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
== References == *Abend-David, Dror, [https://www.amazon.com/Scorned-Nation-Translations-Comparative-Literatures/dp/0820457981/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1284135061&sr=1-1 ''"Scorned My Nation": A Comparison of Translations of The Merchant of Venice into German, Hebrew, and Yiddish''], New York: Peter-Lang, 2003. {{ISBN|978-0-8204-5798-7}}. *[[Jacob Pavlovich Adler|Adler, Jacob]], ''A Life on the Stage: A Memoir'', translated and with commentary by Lulla Rosenfeld, New York: Knopf, 1999. {{ISBN|0-679-41351-0}}. *{{cite book|last=Bloom|first=Harold|authorlink=Harold Bloom|editor=Heims, Neil|title=The Merchant of Venice|publisher=Infobase|location=New York|year=2007|isbn=0-7910-9576-2|pages=}} *Caldecott, Henry Stratford: ''Our English Homer; or, the Bacon-Shakespeare Controversy'' (''[[The Times (South Africa)|Johannesburg Times]]'', 1895). *{{cite book |title = The Merchant of Venice |last = Shakespeare |first = William |authorlink = William Shakespeare |display-authors = 0 |editor1-last = Drakakis |editor1-first = John |series = [[The Arden Shakespeare]], third series |publisher = [[Bloomsbury]] |year = 2010 |isbn = 9781903436813 |doi = 10.5040/9781408160398.00000006 |via = [[Bloomsbury Drama Online]] |subscription = yes |ref = {{harvid|Drakakis|2010}} }} *Gross, John, [https://www.amazon.com/Shylock-Legend-Legacy-John-Gross/dp/0671883860/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1284358222&sr=8-3 ''Shylock: A Legend and Its Legacy''], US: Touchstone, 2001. {{ISBN|0-671-88386-0}}; {{ISBN|978-0-671-88386-7}}. *{{cite book|last=Short|first=Hugh|editor=Mahon, John W. |editor2=Mahon, Ellen Macleod|title=The Merchant of Venice: New Critical Essays|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0-415-92999-8|page=201|chapter=Shylock is content}} *Smith, Rob: ''Cambridge Student Guide to The Merchant of Venice''. {{ISBN|0-521-00816-6}}. *Yaffe, Martin D.: ''Shylock and the Jewish Question''.
==Further reading== {{refbegin|30em}} *{{cite journal |title = Gypsies, Jews, and ''The Merchant of Venice'' |last = McKendy |first = Thomas |journal = [[The English Journal]] |publisher = [[National Council of Teachers of English]] |issn = 0013-8274 |volume = 77 |issue = 7 |year = 1988 |pages = 24–26 |doi = 10.2307/818931 |jstor = 818931 |via = [[JSTOR]] |subscription = y |ref = none }} *{{cite journal |title = A 'Bangzi ''Merchant of Venice''' in Taipei: ''Yue/Shu'' (''Bond'') |last = Perng |first = Ching-Hsi |journal = [[Asian Theatre Journal]] |publisher = [[University of Hawai'i Press]] |issn = 0742-5457 |eissn = 1527-2109 |volume = 28 |issue = 1 |year = 2011 |pages = 222–233 |jstor = 41306478 |via = [[JSTOR]] |subscription = y |ref = none }} {{refend}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5) ([[User:Artix Kreiger|Artix Kreiger]])
revision.text:
[[Image:Paper Chase Book.jpg|thumb|First edition ([[Houghton Mifflin]], 1971)|220px|alt=Paper airplane with the address to Harvard Law School at green-ish blue background and above the red title "THE PAPER CHASE".]] '''''The Paper Chase''''' is a 1971 novel written by [[John Jay Osborn, Jr.]], a 1970 graduate of [[Harvard Law School]]. The book tells the story of Hart, a first-year [[Law school|law student]] at Harvard, and his experiences with Professor Charles Kingsfield, the brilliant, demanding [[contract]]s instructor whom he both idolizes and finds incredibly intimidating.
The novel inspired an eponymous 1973 film and then a television series, which ran from 1978 to 1979 and from 1983 to 1986.
Osborn wrote the novel as a third-year student at Harvard Law School. [[William Alfred]], a Harvard humanities professor and playwright, coached him in writing the book.<ref>{{cite news|title=Former Professor, Playwright Alfred Dies|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1999/5/24/former-professor-playwright-alfred-dies-pthe/|accessdate=29 June 2013|newspaper=The Harvard Crimson|date=May 24, 1999}}</ref>
==Plot== The story centers on Hart, a young law student from Minnesota who attends Harvard Law School and becomes obsessed with one of his teachers, Professor Charles W. Kingsfield, Jr. Hart becomes an expert on Kingsfield's subject, contracts; he reads everything about the subject, including all of Kingsfield's papers, most of which are not on the reading list. He goes so far as to break into the law library to read Kingsfield's original law school notes. Hart becomes such an expert that Kingsfield asks him to contribute to a paper.
At the same time, he begins a relationship with Susan Field, who turns out to be Kingsfield's daughter. Susan stands aloof from the law-school rat-race and dismisses all the things Hart cares about most.
After much effort preparing for the final exam, Hart's grade is delivered to him, but he simply makes a paper airplane out of his final report card, and sends it sailing into the Atlantic Ocean without looking at it.
==Professor Charles W. Kingsfield Jr== Professor Charles W. Kingsfield Jr. is one of the key characters in the novel, film and television series. Kingsfield is an imperious, highly respected (and feared) professor of contracts at Harvard Law School, known for his unrelenting use of the [[Socratic method]] on his students.
Kingsfield himself was a law student at Harvard, as shown by the presence of his own class notes in the institution's archives. Kingsfield has a daughter with a fiercely independent personality.
During an event at Harvard Law School to commemorate the fortieth anniversary of the book's release, the author said that the character was a composite of several of his professors at Harvard Law School, saying, "It wasn’t like it was hard to find role models."<ref>{{cite news|last=Walsh|first=Colleen|title=‘The Paper Chase’ at 40|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2012/10/the-paper-chase-at-40/|accessdate=29 June 2013|newspaper=Harvard Gazette|date=October 2, 2012}}</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mt_lzEjqj0c 'The Paper Chase' at 40: A conversation with author John Jay Osborn Jr. '70]</ref> Many Harvard Law graduates believe the character to be a composite of Contracts professor Clark Byse <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thesecretplot.com/downloadables/Clark_Byse.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202134059/http://www.thesecretplot.com/downloadables/Clark_Byse.pdf |archivedate=2014-02-02 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.law.harvard.edu/news/bulletin/2008/winter/mem-byse.php</ref> and Property Law professor A.J. Casner, legendary intimidating users of the Socratic method. Osborn has stated that Contracts was his favorite law school course.<ref>{{cite news|last=Garcia|first=Ken|title=Father of the 'Paper Chase' / San Francisco writer helped define Harvard|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Father-of-the-Paper-Chase-San-Francisco-2676889.php||newspaper=The San Francisco Chronicle|date=January 28, 2003}}</ref> [[John Houseman]], who played the role in the film and television series, said that he based his performance, in part, on stories he was told by former students of Earl Henry Warren, a professor at the law school from 1904–45. Warren, who taught a first-year property-law course, was famous at the school for his sarcastic comments during lectures and intimidating manner. Houseman's performance was also based on his experience as a professor and director of the drama department at the [[Juilliard School]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Houseman|first=John|title=Tyrannical? Terrifying? You Should Have Met the Real Professor Kingsfield!|url=http://picasaweb.google.com/stuart.fanning/JohnHousemanThePaperChaseTVSeriesTVGuideArticleAugust91986#|accessdate=29 June 2013|newspaper=TV Guide|date=August 9, 1986|pages=36–8}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Structure== The novel is divided into three sections: Fall (chapters 1–15), Winter (chapters 16–33), and Spring (chapters 34–58). Chapters 1, 3, 13, 27, and 35 begin with quotes that set the tone for those chapters.
==40th anniversary edition==
In 2010, a 40th-anniversary edition of ''The Paper Chase'' was released by Peninsula Road Press, which contains a new preface. This edition is the only one prepared by the author.
==Adaptations==
===Film=== {{Main article|The Paper Chase (film)}} According to Osborn, the 1973 film is based "almost word for word" on the novel. It starred [[John Houseman]] as Kingsfield and [[Timothy Bottoms]] as Hart.
===Television series=== {{Main article|The Paper Chase (TV series)}} [[CBS]] aired a one-hour drama series in the 1978–1979 season based on the movie. [[John Houseman]] reprised his movie role, and [[James Stephens (actor)|James Stephens]] played Hart. In 1983, pay-[[cable television|cable]] network [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] brought back the show with both Houseman and Stephens. At the end of three seasons on Showtime, Hart finally graduated.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{The Paper Chase}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Paper Chase, The}} [[Category:1971 American novels]] [[Category:American novels adapted into films]] [[Category:Harvard Law School]] [[Category:Houghton Mifflin books]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in art]]

Mike Binder
[[Renée Humphrey]]
[[Christopher Lawford]]
[[Kevin Pollak]]
[[Stephen Baldwin]]
[[Anita Barone]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = | released = 1999 | runtime = | country = | language = | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Sex Monster''''' is a 1999 American [[comedy film]] directed and written by [[Mike Binder]]. == Plot == Martin "Marty" Barnes, a [[neuroticism|neurotic]] [[businessman]] (director-writer [[Mike Binder]]) who works as a building contractor in Los Angeles, tries to improve his [[sex life]] with his wife Laura ([[Mariel Hemingway]]) by encouraging her to have a [[Ménage à trois|threesome]] involving another woman. Though Marty is fortunate enough to find that Laura likes the idea, he does not count on her decision that she not only has no need of her husband for enjoyment with ladies but also ends up actually preferring them to men. Nor does he anticipate her becoming a sexual tigress who seduces every female she encounters, including even Marty's own secretary. == Cast == * Mike Binder as Marty Barnes * [[Mariel Hemingway]] as Laura Barnes * [[Renée Humphrey]] as Didi * [[Christopher Lawford]] as Dave Pembroke *Joanna Heimbold as Evie Pembroke * [[Kevin Pollak]] as Dr. Jerry Berman * [[Stephen Baldwin]] as Murphy * [[Anita Barone]] as Carol == External links == * {{IMDb title|0159730}} * {{amg title|180321}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|sex_monster|The Sex Monster}} {{Mike Binder}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sex Monster, The}} [[Category:1990s comedy films]] [[Category:1990s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:1999 films]] [[Category:American LGBT-related films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Female bisexuality in film]] [[Category:Films directed by Mike Binder]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:Trimark Pictures films]] {{1990s-comedy-film-stub}} {{LGBT-film-stub}}

{{Infobox religious building | building_name =Vannes Cathedral
{{lang|fr|Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes}} | infobox_width = | image =Vannes cathedral front.jpg | image_size = | caption =Vannes Cathedral | map_type = | map_size = | map_caption = | location =[[Vannes]], {{flag|France}} | geo ={{coord|47.658|N|2.757|W|type:landmark|display=title}} | latitude = | longitude = | religious_affiliation =[[Roman Catholic Church]] | rite =[[Roman Rite|Roman]] | region =[[Morbihan]] | state = | province =[[Bishop of Vannes]] | territory = | prefecture = | sector = | district = | cercle = | municipality = | consecration_year = | status =[[Cathedral]], [[basilica minor]] | functional_status =Active | heritage_designation = | leadership = | website = | architecture =yes | architect = | architecture_type =[[church architecture|church]] | architecture_style =[[Gothic architecture|Gothic]], [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] | general_contractor = | facade_direction = | groundbreaking =11th century | year_completed =18th century | construction_cost = | specifications = | capacity = | length = | width = | width_nave = | height_max = | dome_quantity = | dome_height_outer = | dome_height_inner = | dome_dia_outer = | dome_dia_inner = | minaret_quantity = | minaret_height = | spire_quantity = | spire_height = }} '''Vannes Cathedral''' ({{lang-fr|Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[church architecture|church]] dedicated to [[Saint Peter]] in [[Vannes]], [[Brittany]], [[France]]. The [[cathedral]] is the seat of the [[Bishop of Vannes]]. The present [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] church was erected on the site of the former [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] cathedral. Its construction lasted from the 15th to the 19th centuries; if the length of the existence of the 13th century Romanesque [[bell tower]] is included, a total of seven centuries of construction. The cathedral was declared a [[basilica minor]] by [[Pope Pius IX]] on 5 June 1870.[http://www.cathedrale-vannes.fr/index.php/cathedrale-exterieur/3-exterieur/detail/2-cathe02exthd?tmpl=component#3 Vannes Cathedral website: basilica] {{fr icon}} ==History== The first building was erected around 1020 in Romanesque style. Built out of [[granite]] and continuously modified by adding new structures, the cathedral is an extremely composite building. The rebuilding in Gothic style dates mainly from the 15th and 16th centuries. In this period the [[nave]] and the ornate gateway at the northern end of the north transept – whose twelve niches, according to Breton custom, were supposed to accommodate the [[Twelve Apostles|Apostles]] – were built high. The northern tower is the main remnant of the former Romanesque building, while the [[vault (architecture)|vault]]s and the [[Choir (architecture)|choir]] were built between 1771 and 1774. ==Architecture== [[File:VannesGroundPlan.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Floor plan|Ground plan]] of the cathedral itself.]] ===Dimensions=== The horizontal dimensions of the building can be derived from the [[floor plan|ground plan]]. (Data on the heights are not available for the moment). The building is one of the largest on the French Atlantic coast. ===Exterior=== The [[facade|façade]] was carved in 1857 in a neo-Gothic style. Outside, in front of the central pillar of the large gate, stands a statue of the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] monk [[Vincent Ferrer|St. Vincent Ferrer]], from [[Valencia, Spain|Valencia]]. His activities in the 15th century greatly influenced [[Christianity]] in Vannes. The northern façade opens onto the garden of the [[cloister]] (ruins from the 16th century) and the ''Rue des chanoines'' ("Street of the Canons") through the beautiful portal at the top of the north [[transept]], built in a [[Flamboyant]] late Gothic style (1514), and decorated with twelve niches designed to house statues of the twelve apostles. The cross, visible close to the northern façade, dates back to the 15th century and was brought from the [[cemetery]]. ===Interior=== [[File:VannesChoir.jpg|thumb|left|The nave with the altar and statues of St. Peter and St. Paul (December 2006)]] [[File:Bretagne Morbihan Vannes4 tango7174.jpg|thumb|left|The main altar]] During the [[Middle Ages]], the floor of the cathedral had been covered by [[tombstone]]s. For hygienic reasons, only the tradition of burying the [[bishop]]s in their episcopal church has been preserved. However, some tombstones have been returned and can be seen today. The cathedral has only retained [[tomb]]s dating back to the 17th century. Two bishops' tombs can be found in the [[crypt]] under the choir. The building contains the following features: *''Chapel of the Ancient Baptismal Fonts'' (pos. 1 ground plan): this chapel is too small for actual [[baptism|baptizing]] to take place, but carries the spirit of baptism. The feeling is further enhanced by the [[stained glass]] window, displaying motifs of baptism. *''St. Anne's Chapel'' (pos. 2): [[Saint Anne]] is the patron saint of Brittany. Here, as in [[Nantes Cathedral]], she enjoys special attention, especially with her statue. The stained glass window shows the [[pilgrimage]] of Saint [[Anne d'Auray]], other important events of her life, and one of the [[Blessed Virgin Mary|Blessed Virgin]]. *''Chapel of the Rosary of the Saints Hearts'' (pos. 3): the stained glass window is one of the first showing the Sacred Heart of [[Paray-le-Monial|Paray]]. It is related to the window above the choir. *''Chapel of the Blessed Pierre René Roque'' (pos. 4): Blessed [[Pierre René Roque]] (1758-1796) [http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=375] was a [[priest]], born in Vannes, known for his strong devotion to religion. He was condemned to death and [[guillotine]]d for bringing [[Eucharist|communion]] to a dying man; he was beatified in 1934. He is buried under the altar. [[File:Bretagne Morbihan Vannes7 tango7174.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|St. Gwenaël's Chapel]] [[File:Bretagne Morbihan Vannes8 tango7174.jpg|thumb|upright=0.7|Chapel of St. Mériadec and St. Patern]] *''St. Gwenaël's Chapel'', south entrance (pos. 5): [[Saint Gwenaël]][http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=3615] took part in the [[evangelism|evangelization]] of the [[List of Ancien Régime dioceses of France|West Diocese]] in the 6th century. In the stained glass window he is represented in the company of Blessed [[Françoise d'Amboise]], [[Peter II, Duke of Brittany|duchess of Brittany]] and the founder of the first [[convent]] of the [[Carmelites]] in Vannes. *''The Liturgical Choir'': the three [[Davide Antonio Fossati|Fossati]] altars date back to the 18th century. The statues of [[Simon Peter|Saints Peter]] and [[Paul of Tarsus|Paul]] are placed above the two small altars. *''Our Lady of Lourdes' Chapel'', south [[transept]] (pos. 6): this is the place of the old door of the [[Dukes of Brittany]]. The stained glass window shows the [[First Communion]] of Françoise d'Amboise. Above the window is Saint Peter, to the left a painting of the ascent of [[Saint Petronilla]] [http://www.stpetschurch.org/patroness.htm] [http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=1034] to Heaven. Before the [[French Revolution]], this was the site of the tomb of St. Gwenaël. To the right of the altar Mme. Francheville is buried, a local mystic. *''Ambulatory'' (pos. 7): the [[ambulatory]] is very large to accommodate the [[pilgrim]]s that used to pray at the tomb of St. Vincent Ferrer in the Middle Ages. A marble tablet indicates the affiliation of the cathedral to [[St. Peter's Basilica]] in [[Rome]]. The cathedral in Vannes also carries the title of Basilica. *''The Treasury'' (pos. 8): this room was constructed in about 1782 in a part of the Romanesque choir. The walls are covered with beautiful woodwork and panelling. The shelves contain books on [[theology]] and religious history. The most remarkable item is a box made of wood and covered with painted [[parchment]] of southern origin. It dates back to the 12th century and is decorated with scenes of daily life. Among the other notable objects of the treasury are a gold cross and two ivory sticks. [[File:VannesStAnn.jpg|thumb|left|Saint Anne's Chapel in Vannes Cathedral (December 2006)]] *''Portal of the Canons'', north transept (pos. 13): [[Vincent Ferrer|St. Vincent Ferrer]]'s tomb was located here until 1956. There is still a stained glass window depicting him. There are also two paintings, one by Gosse (1945) and one by Mauzaise (1831). The former shows the death of the saint and the latter depicts him preaching to [[infidel]]s. This is the place where baptism is currently celebrated. *''Our Lady of Mercy Chapel'' (pos. 14): here there is a painting of the [[Virgin and child]] by Delaval (1836). There is also a stained glass window showing [[Ivo of Kermartin|Saint Yves]]. He enjoys a special position in all Breton churches, as a patron saint of the Breton [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|Rector]]s, and also as the main defender of the independence of the Breton churches against the royal power. *''St. Vincent Ferrer's Chapel'' (pos. 15): this was formerly the chapel of the [[Holy Sacrament]], but since 1956 it has housed the [[relic]]s of Saint Vincent Ferrer, including his [[human skull|skull]]. *''St. Anthony's Chapel'', north entrance (pos. 16): here there is a painting by Vincent from 1830 depicting [[Jesus Christ]] on the Cross, [[John the Apostle|Saint John]], the Holy Virgin and Saint [[Mary Magdalene]]. *''Chapel of St. Mériadec and St. Patern'' (pos. 18): the stained glass window here represents [[Saint Meriadec]] [http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=5092] and [[Saint Patern]], the first [[Bishop of Vannes]]. There are also paintings, one by Rivoulon from 1846, "Litanies of the Holy Virgin", and one by Destouches from 1819 of the [[Resurrection]] of Saint [[Lazarus of Bethany|Lazarus]]. *''Romanesque tower'' (pos. 19): this is the only structure left from the Romanesque cathedral. It accommodates the four bells of the church. Positions 9, 10, 11, 13 and 17 are the Blessed Sacrament Chapel (closed to visitors), the Chapel of Our Lady ''de Pitié'', the Chapel in the [[apse]], the [[Calvary]] and the Chapel of St. Louis respectively. ==In literature== In the novels of [[Alexandre Dumas, père|Alexandre Dumas]], the [[musketeer]] [[Aramis]] appears at one point as Bishop of Vannes and logically must have served in this very cathedral. ==Burials== *[[Isabella of Scotland, Duchess of Brittany]] * St. [[Vincent Ferrer]] ==Gallery== File:Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes (1).JPG Image:Vannes - Centre ville.jpg Image:VannesCathedral.jpg Image:Cathedrale vannes.jpg File:Vannes Saint-Vincent 0708.jpg File:Bretagne Morbihan Vannes5 tango7174.jpg File:Bretagne Morbihan Vannes6 tango7174.jpg File:Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes (2).JPG File:Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes (6).JPG File:Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes (5).JPG ==References== ==External links== {{commons category|Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Vannes}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061125054215/http://www.monum.fr/visitez/decouvrir/fiche.dml?lang=fr&id=126 Monum.fr] {{fr icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070322195159/http://www.nieuwsbronnen.com/camping-manoir-surzur/cathedrale.html Tourism site] {{fr icon}} * [http://www.culture.gouv.fr/culture/inventai/itiinv/cathedrale/docimage/vannes/cat_vannes.html Ministère de Culture: archive photographs] {{fr icon}} * [http://fr.structurae.de/structures/data/index.cfm?id=s0015116 Structurae: images only] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals in France]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches completed in 1774]] [[Category:Basilica churches in France]] [[Category:Gothic architecture in France]] [[Category:Churches in Morbihan]] [[Category:Vannes]] [[Category:Monuments historiques of Morbihan]]

'''''Vasilissa ergo gaude''''' ("''Therefore rejoice, [[basilissa|princess]]''") is an [[isorhythm]]ic [[motet]] by the [[Renaissance]] composer [[Guillaume Dufay]]. In terms of its subject matter, it is sometimes grouped together with ''[[Lamentatio sanctae matris ecclesiae Constantinopolitanae]]'', ''[[Apostolus gloriosus]]'' and ''[[Balsamus et munda cera]]'' which are generically called Dufay's ''Byzantine motets''.<ref>Margaret Vardell Sandresky, "The Golden Section in Three Byzantine Motets of Dufay", ''Journal of Music Theory'', Vol. 25, No. 2 (Autumn, 1981), pp. 291–306</ref> Its composition was occasioned by the marriage on 21 January 1421 of [[Cleofa Malatesta]], daughter of Malatesta di Pandolfo, to [[Theodore II Palaiologos]] son of the Byzantine emperor [[Manuel II Palaiologos|Manuel II]] and [[Despot (court title)|Despot]] of the [[Despotate of Morea|Morea]].<ref>J. Michael Allsen, "Intertextuality and Compositional Process in Two Cantilena Motets by Hugo de Lantins", ''The Journal of Musicology'', Vol. 11, No. 2 (Spring, 1993), p. 176, footnote 6</ref> It has been surmised that the actual motet was composed in 1420 and is perhaps the earliest example of this choral form if not the earliest work attributed to Dufay.<ref>Howard Mayer Brown, "Guillaume Dufay and the Early Renaissance", ''Early Music'', Vol. 2, No. 4 (Oct., 1974), p. 221</ref> In earlier scholarship it was assumed that the motet's first performance had taken place on May 19, 1419 during the festivities prior to the marriage <ref>Johannes Wolf, "Der niederlandische Einfluss in der mehrstimmigen gemessenen Musik bis zum Jahre 1480. Eine bibliographische Skizze", ''Tijdschrift der Vereeniging voor Noord-Nederlands Muziekgeschiedenis'', D. 6de, 4de Stuk (1900), p.223</ref>
{| |- |<poem> Vasilissa, ergo gaude, Quia es digna omni laude, Cleophe, clara gestis A tuis de Malatestis, In Italia principibus Magnis et nobilibus, </poem> |<poem> Therefore rejoice, [[basilissa|princess]], for you are worthy of all praise, Cleofe, glorious from the deeds of your [[House of Malatesta|Malatesta]] kin, leading men in Italy, great and noble, </poem> |- |<poem> Ex tuo viro clarior, Quia cunctis est nobilior: Romeorum est despotus, Quem colit mundus totus; In porphyro est genitus, A deo missus celitus </poem> |<poem> More glorious from your husband, for he is nobler than all; he is [[Despot (court title)|Despot]] of the [[Rhomaioi]], he whom all the world reveres; he was [[Porphyrogenitos|born in the purple]], sent by god from heaven </poem> |- |<poem> Iuvenili etate polles et formositate <Ingenio> multum fecunda Et utraque lingua facunda Ac clarior es virtutibus Pre alliis hominibus. </poem> |<poem> In youthfull bloom you abound and in beauty, very fertile <in your wits> and eloquent in both tongues, and you are more glorious for your virtues above other human beings. </poem> |- |<poem> ''Tenor'' Concupivit rex decorem tuum Quoniam ipse est dominus tuus </poem> |<poem> ''Tenor'' The king hath conceived desire for thy beauty, for he is thy Lord.<ref>The translated text is based almost entirely on Leofranc Holford-Strevens, "Du Fay the Poet? Problems in the Texts of His Motets", ''Early Music History'', Vol. 16, (1997), pp. 102–103</ref></poem> |}
The tenor line is taken from [[Psalm]] 45:11 (44:11 in the traditional Catholic numbering), whose theme is royal marriage. The verse chosen for the motet occurs in Catholic liturgy in the [[Gradual]] of various feasts of [[the Virgin Mary]].<ref>[http://gregorien.info/php/all-about-a-title.php?keyTitle=337&lang=en&template=gregorien-info Académie de Chant grégorien]</ref> The motet is preserved in the contemporary music manuscript Codex Bologna, [[International museum and library of music]], MS Q15. In terms of structure the composition has been compared with the mature work of [[Johannes Ciconia]], a Franco-Flemish composer also active in Italy. Of the four voices used, the two upper voices bearing the melody often imitate each other and move faster than the two lower voices. The [[Isorhythm|talea]] is repeated only once. An additional device independent from the motet's purely isorhythmic design is the canonic introit (a short [[Canon (music)|canon]] used as a prelude) appearing at the beginning of the composition.<ref>Howard Mayer Brown, "Guillaume Dufay and the Early Renaissance", ''Early Music'', Vol. 2, No. 4 (Oct., 1974), p. 222–3</ref>
Even though numerological mysticism which is often encountered in the [[Ars Antiqua]] seems to have been of minor importance in musical composition from the 14th century onwards,<ref>[http://www.acc.umu.se/~akadkor/early/IID.html Umeå Akademiska Kör] Early Vocal Music Map</ref> there have been attempts to interpret the motet's texture and design from a symbolic-mystical viewpoint. Dufay is known to have utilised similar devices such as [[gematria]] (a system of number symbolism drawn from the Pythagorean corpus) in other nuptial compositions.<ref>Allan W. Atlas , "Gematria, Marriage Numbers, and Golden Sections in Dufay's 'Resvellies vous'",'' Acta Musicologica'', Vol. 59, Fasc. 2 (May – August, 1987), pp. 111</ref> The tenor line singing the [[Cantus firmus]] in ''Vasilissa ergo gaude'' consists of a total of 2x49 notes plus the two closing notes which add to a total of 100 notes. It has been suggested that this number implies the medieval symbolism for repentance which leads to absolute unity. It has further been proposed that the number 100 should be related to the total of 700 or else 7x100 notes of the remaining three voices, alluding thus to the sacred number 7. The sum total of notes in the motet is 800 and this has been interpreted as an allusion to the number 8. In medieval numerology, 8 signified eternity, understood in the context of Dufay's motet as eternal stability.
All these numerical symbolisms must have had a particular significance in view of the politically motivated marriage between Cleofa Malatesta and Theodore Palaiologos. The marriage was arranged as part of a series of diplomatic gestures between Cleofa's uncle [[Pope Martin V]] and the Byzantine emperor. It was hoped that it would facilitate reunification between the Roman Catholic and the Eastern Orthodox Church (cf. [[Council of Florence]]).<ref>Review by Jaap van Benthem, Reviewed work: ''Dufay by David Fallows'', in ''Tijdschrift van de Vereniging voor Nederlandse Muziekgeschiedenis'', D. 33ste, Afl. 1ste/2de (1983), p. 111</ref>
